results.title: Waco: the rules of engagement
results.creator_credit: William Gazecki, Michael McNulty, Dan Gifford and Fifth Estate Productions
results.brief_description: This film presents amazing revelations about what really went on at Waco, Texas in 1993 when 76 men, women and children and 4 federal agents died in the siege of the compound of David Koresh’ religious sect. Through a collation of news footage, coverage of the Senate hearings after the tragedy, tapes of 911 phone calls, and interviews with experts and survivors, we are given a very different picture to that which the United States Senate would have us believe. There is no narrator in this documentary, rather Gazecki presents the evidence through the words of the experts, those who were on the scene of the tragedy and who knew the sect members. In this film you will see what the media did not show us, and it is an enlightening view of how marginal groups are treated in our democratic society.

results.title: Kurt & Courtney
results.brief_description: Nick Broomfield’s controversial documentary “Kurt & Courtney” looks at the volatile relationship between Nirvana rock legend Kurt Cobain and Courtney Love, whose career as lead singer of Hole and as an actress took off not long after Cobain’s death. As well as attempting to delve into the psyches of Cobain and Love (aka Frances Farmer), Broomfield looks at the various theories surrounding Cobain’s death, which was shrouded in mystery and which instantly became part of the long list of conspiracy theories which our society finds so compelling. Broomfield’s documentary is in no way objective, but it is fascinating to watch, as the director pointedly incorporates his own battle to get his film made with Courtney Love vehemently attempting to stop the film. With home footage of Cobain and interviews with people who knew Cobain and Love, this is a must see for Nirvana fans (although due to legal constraints Broomfield could not use any music by Nirvana in the film). Curiously Kurt remains a shadowy figure in the film, and you actually get a stronger sense of Courtney Love as well as the various ‘hangers on’ who Broomfield interviews throughout the film.

results.title: PANACEA: the documentary
results.creator_credit: Ioannis Ioannou, Cinemedia, Rose Myers, Vanessa Rouse and Arena Theatre Company
results.brief_description: ‘PANACEA the documentary’ follows the journey of Arena Theatre Company’s creative team as they embark on an ambitious large scale performance event fusing modern technology and cinematic devices. A combination of conventional theatre and MTV culture.

results.title: In the footsteps of the pharaohs
results.creator_credit: Greg Grainger and Grainger Television Australia
results.brief_description: Producer and presenter Greg Grainger embarks on a journey into the ancient civilization of Egypt’s past, as well as the vibrancy of modern Egypt. He begins his journey at Abu Simbel near the Sudanese border, sails across dams in Aswan, along the river Nile to Luxor, and in Cairo explores new excavations around the pyramids. Along the way he encounters boatmen, bellydancers, feasts, markets, bazaars, and wedding festivities. The sights and sounds are a lasting legacy of an amazing ancient culture.

results.title: Pokemon: I choose you! Pikachu!
results.creator_credit: Masamitsu Hidaka, Takamoto Mori, Takayuki Yanagisawa, Keisuke Iwata, 4 Kids Productions and Shogakukan Production Co Ltd
results.brief_description: This volume contains the first three episodes of the Japanese (English Dubbed) cartoon. The first episode, entitled “I Choose You! Pikachu!” sees Ash, a ten year old boy get his first Pokemon (pocket monster). Having been late to the ceremony for choosing Pokemon, Ash is left with the last Pokemon, an electric rat Pokemon called Pikachu. After a bumpy start the two learn to work as a team to fight off a flock of Spearows: aggressive flying Pokemon. The second episode, entitled “Pokemon Emergency!” continues from the end of the battle with the Spearows in which Pikachu is badly hurt. Ash then has to rush his Pokemon to the special Pokemon hospital. While Ash waits for Pikachu to recover, the hospital is attacked by Team Rocket, an evil team of Pokemon thieves. Pikachu recovers just in time to work with Ash to scare off Team Rocket. Ash then continues on his quest to become a Pokemon master followed by Misty, a young girl who helped him save Pikachu. In third episode, entitled “Ash Catches a Pokemon”, Ash manages to catch his very first Pokemon, a big Pokemon called Caterpie. While Misty does not like Caterpie to begin with, things start to change after Caterpie saves the day when Team Rocket attempts another attack on Ash, Pikachu and Misty. Pokemon the series is based the Nintendo game of the same name.

results.title: Soldier girls
results.brief_description: Closely follows a group of American women recruits through a grueling six weeks of basic training, during which time, some manage and some fail to come to terms with some of the realities that recruiting brochures never mentioned. Closely follows the four women at Fort Gordon, Georgia through the mental and physical rigors of the camp. “Soldier Girls” was the winner of the 1981 British Film Awards’ best documentary award.

results.title: Yehudi Menuhin: the violin of the century
results.creator_credit: Bruno Monsaingeon, Pierre-Olivier Bardet, INA France, Imalyre-Group France Telecom, La Sept-Arte and Ideale Audience
results.brief_description: A world-class violinist, a committed teacher of young musicians, an active supporter of human rights, a compassionate man. Now in his eighties, Yehudi Menuhin relaxes at home and reflects on his remarkable life. Using a wealth of archival footage, this documentary traces Lord Meuhin’s long and varied career, his childhood, his musical influences, and his humanity for those less fortunate than himself.

results.title: War stories
results.creator_credit: Gaylene Preston and Gaylene Preston Productions
results.brief_description: A revealing documentary that explores the effects of war beyond the battlefield. Through candid interviews with seven elderly women the impact of World War II on the women who were left behind and the men in their lives is constructed in a series of deeply personal and unexpected stories. Combined with newsreel footage and still photographs, the choice and sequence of the womens’ stories woven together by Gaylene Preston provides a powerful and wide-ranging portrait of New Zealand society and the long repressed emotions provoked by the experience of war. (Awards: Best Film in the New Zealand Film and Television Awards, Official Selection Venice Film Festival, most popular film 1995 Sydney Film Festival)

results.title: Beyond El Rocco
results.creator_credit: Kevin Lucas, AFFC and Lucas Produkzions
results.brief_description: ‘Beyond El Rocco’ is an affectionate look at the Australian jazz scene and its evolution through the decades from the swinging 60s through to the experimentalism of the 80s. Tony Barry plays Zoot Finster, a diehard jazz fan who takes us on a personal journey which begins at the El Rocco jazz club in Sydney in the fifties. The film looks not only at the Sydney scene, but brings in developments in Melbourne, including footage of Jazz Centre 44 which was the Melbourne counterpoint to the El Rocco in the fifties. Includes interviews and recordings of sessions with the big names of Australian jazz including Judie Bailey, John Sangster, Don Burrows, Joe Lane, Brian Brown, Bernie McGann, Mike Nock, Roger Frampton, John Pochee, Dale Barlow, Sandy Evans, James Morrison and Paul Grabowski. A must see for jazz fans.

results.title: The Coolbaroo club (A)
results.creator_credit: Roger Scholes, Penny Robins, Australian Film Commission, Coolbaroo Club Productions and Film Finance Corporation Australia
results.brief_description: A study of what life was like for many Aboriginal Australians in post World War 11 Western Australia. For 14 years, between 1946 and 1960, the Coolbaroo Club in Perth, Western Australia, was a meeting place and a community focus for the local Aboriginal community. The Coolbaroo Club was unique in that it was the only Aboriginal-run dance club in a city that was notorious for its unofficial apartheid, police harassment, identity cards for Aboriginals, curfews and bureaucratic obstruction. The club attracted interest from Black musicians both in Australia and overseas. Nat ‘King’ Cole, Harold Blair and the Harlem Globetrotters being among the international celebrities. As well as providing a place where the Aboriginal community could safely gather, the club was also known for its political activities. It issued a newspaper and later became an effective political organisation, speaking out on issues of the day which were affecting Aboriginal people. The exceptional achievement of the Coolbaroo League in finding an affirmative response to white oppression can be seen today as an important step forward in the development of Aboriginal self determination. The film is a powerful record of this achievement.
